org.jtrim2.executor

Class ExecutorsEx

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jtrim2.executor.ExecutorsEx

  • public final class ExecutorsEx
extends java.lang.Object
    This class contains static helper and factory methods for Executors and ExecutorServices. This class amongst others, allows new executors to be created not provided by Executors.

    This class cannot be inherited and instantiated.

    Thread safety

    Unless otherwise noted, methods of this class are safe to use by multiple threads concurrently.

    Synchronization transparency

    Unless otherwise noted, methods of this class are synchronization transparent.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  ExecutorsEx.NamedThreadFactory
      A ThreadFactory which creates thread with names containing a specified string and a given daemon status and also belong to the same thread group.

    • Method Detail

      • canceledFuture

        public static <T> java.util.concurrent.Future<T> canceledFuture()
        Returns a future representing a canceled task. Attempting to retrieve its result (by a call to one of its get methods) will cause an CancellationException to be thrown. The future is considered to be not done and canceled, so canceling it will always succeed.

        Thread safety

        This method and the methods of the returned Future is safe to use by multiple threads concurrently.

        Synchronization transparency

        This method and the methods of the returned Future is synchronization transparent.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the result of the returned Future. Note that no such value can actually be retrieved from the returned Future.
        Returns:
        the future representing a canceled task

      • shutdownExecutorsNow

        public static void shutdownExecutorsNow(java.util.concurrent.ExecutorService... executors)
        Invokes the shutdownNow() method of all the specified executors.
        Parameters:
        executors - the executors to be shutted down. This argument cannot be null and cannot contain null elements.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if the argument is null or any of its elements is null

      • shutdownExecutorsNow

        public static void shutdownExecutorsNow(java.util.Collection<? extends java.util.concurrent.ExecutorService> executors)
        Invokes the shutdownNow() method of all the executors in the given collection.
        Parameters:
        executors - the executors to be shutted down. This argument cannot be null and cannot contain null elements.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if the argument is null or any of its elements is null

      • awaitExecutor

        public static void awaitExecutor(java.util.concurrent.ExecutorService executor)
                          throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Waits until the specified ExecutorService terminates. That is, this method waits until no more tasks will be executed by the given ExecutorService.
        Parameters:
        executor - the executor waited to be terminated. This argument cannot be null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException - thrown if the current thread was interrupted before the executor was terminated
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if the specified executor is null

      • awaitExecutors

        public static void awaitExecutors(java.util.concurrent.ExecutorService... executors)
                           throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Waits until all the specified ExecutorServices terminate. That is, this method waits until no more tasks will be executed by the specified ExecutorServices.
        Parameters:
        executors - the executors waited to be terminated. This argument cannot be null and cannot contain null elements.
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException - thrown if the current thread was interrupted before at least one of the executor was terminated
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if the argument is null or any of its elements is null

      • awaitExecutors

        public static void awaitExecutors(java.util.Collection<? extends java.util.concurrent.ExecutorService> executors)
                           throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Waits until all the ExecutorServices in the specified collection terminate. That is, this method waits until no more tasks will be executed by the specified ExecutorServices.
        Parameters:
        executors - the executors waited to be terminated. This argument cannot be null and cannot contain null elements.
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException - thrown if the current thread was interrupted before at least one of the executor was terminated
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if the argument is null or any of its elements is null

      • awaitExecutors

        public static boolean awaitExecutors(long timeout,
                                     java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit timeunit,
                                     java.util.concurrent.ExecutorService... executors)
                              throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Waits until all the specified ExecutorServices terminate or the given timeout elapses. That is, this method waits until no more tasks will be executed by the specified ExecutorServices or the specified timeout elapses.
        Parameters:
        timeout - the maximum time to wait in the given time unit
        timeunit - the time unit of the timeout argument. This argument cannot be null.
        executors - the executors waited to be terminated. This argument cannot be null and cannot contain null elements.
        Returns:
        true if all the executors have terminated, false if at least on of the executors has not yet terminated
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException - thrown if the current thread was interrupted before at least one of the executor was terminated
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if the timeunit or executors argument is null or any of the elements of executors is null

      • awaitExecutors

        public static boolean awaitExecutors(long timeout,
                                     java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit timeunit,
                                     java.util.Collection<? extends java.util.concurrent.ExecutorService> executors)
                              throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Waits until all the ExecutorServices in the specified collection terminate or the given timeout elapses. That is, this method waits until no more tasks will be executed by the specified ExecutorServices or the specified timeout elapses.
        Parameters:
        timeout - the maximum time to wait in the given time unit
        timeunit - the time unit of the timeout argument. This argument cannot be null.
        executors - the executors waited to be terminated. This argument cannot be null and cannot contain null elements.
        Returns:
        true if all the executors have terminated, false if at least on of the executors has not yet terminated
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException - thrown if the current thread was interrupted before at least one of the executor was terminated
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if the timeunit or executors argument is null or any of the elements of executors is null

      • asUnstoppableExecutor

        public static java.util.concurrent.ExecutorService asUnstoppableExecutor(java.util.concurrent.ExecutorService executor)
        Returns an ExecutorService forwarding all of its methods to the given ExecutorService but the returned ExecutorService cannot be shutted down. Attempting to shutdown the returned ExecutorService results in an unchecked UnsupportedOperationException to be thrown.
        Parameters:
        executor - the executor to which calls to be forwarded by the returned ExecutorService. This argument cannot be null.
        Returns:
        an ExecutorService which forwards all of its calls to the specified executor but cannot be shutted down. This method never returns null.

      • newMultiThreadedExecutor

        public static java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor newMultiThreadedExecutor(int maxThreadCount,
                                                                               boolean isDaemon)
        Creates a new ThreadPoolExecutor which will use at most the specified maximum thread count and daemon status. The executor will have a default name and one second timeout before its core threads will terminate if there are no tasks available. Note that every thread of the executor will eventually terminate if no tasks are submitted to the executor even if it was not shutted down (and will be restarted on demand).
        Parameters:
        maxThreadCount - the maximum number of threads to be used by the returned executor. This argument must be greater than zero.
        isDaemon - the daemon status of the threads used by the returned executor. Note that the JVM will terminate if there are only daemon threads are remaining.
        Returns:
        the newly created ThreadPoolExecutor preinitialized with the requested properties. This method never returns null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - thrown if maxThreadCount is not greater than zero
        See Also:
        newMultiThreadedExecutor(int, long, boolean, String)

      • newMultiThreadedExecutor

        public static java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor newMultiThreadedExecutor(int maxThreadCount,
                                                                               boolean isDaemon,
                                                                               java.lang.String poolName)
        Creates a new ThreadPoolExecutor which will use at most the specified maximum thread count, daemon status and name. The executor will have a one second timeout before its core threads will terminate if there are no tasks available. Note that every thread of the executor will eventually terminate if no tasks are submitted to the executor even if it was not shutted down (and will be restarted on demand).
        Parameters:
        maxThreadCount - the maximum number of threads to be used by the returned executor. This argument must be greater than zero.
        isDaemon - the daemon status of the threads used by the returned executor. Note that the JVM will terminate if there are only daemon threads are remaining.
        poolName - the name of the returned executor useful for debugging purposes. This string will be part of the name of the threads created by the returned executor. This argument can be null in which case a default name will be given to this executor.
        Returns:
        the newly created ThreadPoolExecutor preinitialized with the requested properties. This method never returns null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - thrown if maxThreadCount is not greater than zero
        See Also:
        newMultiThreadedExecutor(int, long, boolean, String)

      • newMultiThreadedExecutor

        public static java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor newMultiThreadedExecutor(int maxThreadCount,
                                                                               long threadKeepAliveTime,
                                                                               boolean isDaemon)
        Creates a new ThreadPoolExecutor which will use at most the specified maximum thread count, daemon status, and thread keep alive time. The executor will have a default name. Note that every thread of the executor will eventually terminate if the specified thread keep alive time elapses and no tasks are submitted to the executor even if it was not shutted down (and will be restarted on demand).
        Parameters:
        maxThreadCount - the maximum number of threads to be used by the returned executor. This argument must be greater than zero.
        threadKeepAliveTime - the time in milliseconds to wait after the returned executor will shutdown idle threads. This argument must be greater than or equal to zero.
        isDaemon - the daemon status of the threads used by the returned executor. Note that the JVM will terminate if there are only daemon threads are remaining.
        Returns:
        the newly created ThreadPoolExecutor preinitialized with the requested properties. This method never returns null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - thrown if maxThreadCount is not greater than zero or threadKeepAliveTime is a negative integer
        See Also:
        newMultiThreadedExecutor(int, long, boolean, String)

      • newMultiThreadedExecutor

        public static java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor newMultiThreadedExecutor(int maxThreadCount,
                                                                               long threadKeepAliveTime,
                                                                               boolean isDaemon,
                                                                               java.lang.String poolName)
        Creates a new ThreadPoolExecutor which will use at most the specified maximum thread count, daemon status, name and thread keep alive time. Note that every thread of the executor will eventually terminate if the specified thread keep alive time elapses and no tasks are submitted to the executor even if it was not shutted down (and will be restarted on demand).
        Parameters:
        maxThreadCount - the maximum number of threads to be used by the returned executor. This argument must be greater than zero.
        threadKeepAliveTime - the time in milliseconds to wait after the returned executor will shutdown idle threads. This argument must be greater than or equal to zero.
        isDaemon - the daemon status of the threads used by the returned executor. Note that the JVM will terminate if there are only daemon threads are remaining.
        poolName - the name of the returned executor useful for debugging purposes. This string will be part of the name of the threads created by the returned executor. This argument can be null in which case a default name will be given to this executor.
        Returns:
        the newly created ThreadPoolExecutor preinitialized with the requested properties. This method never returns null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - thrown if maxThreadCount is not greater than zero or threadKeepAliveTime is a negative integer
        See Also:
        newMultiThreadedExecutor(int, long, boolean, String)

      • newSchedulerThreadedExecutor

        public static java.util.concurrent.ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor newSchedulerThreadedExecutor(int maxThreadCount,
                                                                                            boolean isDaemon)
        Creates a new ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor which will use at most the specified maximum thread count and daemon status. The executor will have a default name and one second timeout before its core threads will terminate if there are no tasks available. Note that every thread of the executor will eventually terminate if no tasks are submitted to the executor even if it was not shutted down (and will be restarted on demand).
        Parameters:
        maxThreadCount - the maximum number of threads to be used by the returned executor. This argument must be greater than zero.
        isDaemon - the daemon status of the threads used by the returned executor. Note that the JVM will terminate if there are only daemon threads are remaining.
        Returns:
        the newly created ThreadPoolExecutor preinitialized with the requested properties. This method never returns null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - thrown if maxThreadCount is not greater than zero
        See Also:
        newMultiThreadedExecutor(int, long, boolean, String)

      • newSchedulerThreadedExecutor

        public static java.util.concurrent.ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor newSchedulerThreadedExecutor(int maxThreadCount,
                                                                                            boolean isDaemon,
                                                                                            java.lang.String poolName)
        Creates a new ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor which will use at most the specified maximum thread count, daemon status and name. The executor will have a one second timeout before its core threads will terminate if there are no tasks available. Note that every thread of the executor will eventually terminate if no tasks are submitted to the executor even if it was not shutted down (and will be restarted on demand).
        Parameters:
        maxThreadCount - the maximum number of threads to be used by the returned executor. This argument must be greater than zero.
        isDaemon - the daemon status of the threads used by the returned executor. Note that the JVM will terminate if there are only daemon threads are remaining.
        poolName - the name of the returned executor useful for debugging purposes. This string will be part of the name of the threads created by the returned executor. This argument can be null in which case a default name will be given to this executor.
        Returns:
        the newly created ThreadPoolExecutor preinitialized with the requested properties. This method never returns null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - thrown if maxThreadCount is not greater than zero
        See Also:
        newMultiThreadedExecutor(int, long, boolean, String)
